comments.commentBody:
If you want to help "disappear" Donald Trump and have him, mercifully, fade away after November, I suggest you do as I'm going to do.

At least two hours a week on the phone doing voter outreach for Clinton. This is the ground game of identifying and encouraging voters - especially in crucial swing states - to get them to commit to come out on November 8. That's how elections are won. One voter at a time. It's rewarding and fun. All you need is a phone, a laptop or your smartphone.
You can do it in your underwear!

Trump, with his smoke and mirrors campaign (to match his grasp on reality) has lagged far behind in this kind of ground effort. Good. The better to excise him from the American body.

HillaryClinton.com
Hit the "Act" link.

You'll be so glad you made the effort when we bury Donald.
If he doesn't bury himself first!

There is another reason for hope that Hillary’s Poll Bounce will persist through the summer. In typical Trump fashion, he has launched a four day Twitter tirade against the Muslim Gold Star Family, the Khans. As you well know, Mr. Khan was using his First Amendment Rights, when he gave a critique of Trump at the DNC Convention last week. That sent Trump into a Twitter Tizzy. In spite of the negative blowback from Democrats, Veterans’ Groups and some Republicans, Trump still persists in his attacks. Trump cannot help himself.

Basically, Trump is immature and has no impulse control. Trump fits the definition of Impulse Control Disorder NOS. This is “defined as a predisposition toward rapid, unplanned reactions to either internal or external stimuli without regard for negative consequences”

WEB: http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/impulse-control-disorders/impulse-contro...

Based on Trump’s reaction to criticism from Khazir Khan, a private citizen, all of Trump’s followers should be very wary. If Trump were “President” and you used your First Amendment Rights to criticize him or his policies in an Op Ed, Comment or Tweet, “President” Trump would hit you with a barrage of vicious Tweets. Trump would also have the power and prestige of the US Presidency at his finger tips. The Secret Service, FBI, US Justice Department and IRS have wide latitudes of power in our country.
Excellent, looks like Hillary has it in the bag. I probably won't even bother to vote.

It's not only WikiLeaks that is likely to change public opinion. Any further breakout of either police killings or ISIS terrorism will do much to focus the minds of the public on real, as opposed to media manufactured, issues in this election.

And I think that the debates will also favor Trump, although one can predict as well that his performance will be panned by everyone in the increasingly obviously biased media. Why will he be favored? Because, on the issues, it is Clinton, and not Trump, who is totally out of touch with the public.

Who in the larger public thinks that BLM is anything but bad news? Who in the larger public thinks, as does Hillary, that the answer to ISIS terrorism is a vast increase in the number of Muslims allowed to immigrate? Who in the larger public thinks that our exercises in power in Libya and Syria and Iraq have been anything but disasters? Who in the larger public thinks that increased immigration, and globalistic trade deals profits American workers?

The one thing Hillary can't survive is an election based on the issues. And Trump should be able to communicate his position on these issues, and contrast them with Hillary.

The trajectory of Trump's candidacy reminds me of the movie and Broadway play, "The Producers." Trump seems to be doing everything he can, and I mean everything folks, to ensure a huge failure for his candidacy in November. Insulting a Gold Star Family and a fallen American hero is beyond the pale, even for DJT. In the language of Wall Street, he seems to be "shorting" his own run.

That's all ok, until you remember how The Producers ended.

It may not be "Springtime for Hitler", only because the season is wrong. So maybe "Autumn Leaves for Trump" will be a big musical hit later this year.

Sure hope not.
Could you clarify what you mean by white working-class? Just curious about how you delimit that classification.

It's incredible to see how hard the New York Times is rooting for a particular candidate. I understand that Hillary Clinton is, and always has been, a thoroughgoing establishment politician, of the kind that the paper would like to have in power. Nevertheless, the New York Times should at least feigned an attempt to hold the Democratic Party responsible for the categorical fact that it tried to sway the primaries--even if only to maintain its own veneer of fairness and its standing as the liberal voice of record.

Of course, Trump responded to the interviewer's question about the fallen Muslim soldier like an idiot. If he had any intelligence, he would have expressed sympathy to the parents for their loss, and pointed out that if Capt. Humayun Khan had not been deployed in an illegal war that was supported by Clinton enthusiastically, he could have been with his family today.

A lot of people complain about the things Trump says about specific issues, whether military, or geo-political, or economic. On the other hand, most people against Clinton, including the Sanders Democrats, object to the very positions taken by Clinton, not just her well-rehearsed descriptions of her positions. This concerted media onslaught against Trump is actually a proxy propaganda war against Vladimir Putin. Let us hope that some sanity prevails, and the great powers do not come to war in the course of the next few years.

Trump is about equally non-representative of a liberal as a Cruz supporter. If Trump were the democratic nominee and Cruz were the republican nominee, it would be EXTREMELY hard for me to vote for Cruz. I honestly believe republicans hate Hillary far more than any democrat hates Cruz, so I can sympathize with the horrible conflict they must be experiencing.

I want to believe that I'd either stay home or vote Cruz, but who knows?

Now that it is fairly likely that Trump isn't going to win, I think a lot of republicans will refuse to vote for him. Just like how everyone voted for the Iraq war, but it is now seen as a point of failure, people will remember who supported Trump and who refused.

I'm glad to see that a lot of erstwhile Bernie Sanders supporters, and especially Bernie himself, are now determined to elect Hillary Clinton to the White House, but I am afraid if the race tightens up that the diehard Bernie/Jill Stein voters can make a difference in the swing states.  When your ship of state is headed toward the iceberg, all hands are needed on deck.  This is national emergency and a self-righteous determination to stick to progress principles might sink us all.

I don't think there is much danger of complacency in the Clinton camp, especially given the roller-coaster ride we've had so far, the gasps of fear we continue to emit, and the relatively soft support from many of the Bernie voters (not to mention the small but significant sucking sound of those third-party candidates).  What worries me more than any of this, though, is the persistence of those purportedly Russian computer hackers, and Julian Assange's undying antipathy for Hillary.  He has threatened more damaging releases, and is likely just waiting for a strategic moment -- say, right as voters go to the polls? -- to drop another bomb or two.   I'm afraid to buy into the current moment for fear of the next one.

All informed voters need to be active for her because the chance has never been more stark (and I say that as a journalist specializing in presidential history). Please share this documented list of why she's the best candidate with the sane and persuadable (read by 7000 thus far0: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/open-letter-sanders-supporters-scott-s-sm...
Some times I wonder if Trump is really working for Hillary.  If she wasn't running against Trump she would have a chance!

Get voters to turn out for Democrats. The followers of fascists have never been deterred by a candidate's lack of intellect or abundance of hate. They will turn up to vote for Trump no matter what idiotic thing he says next.

Wikileaks has more to release.

The timing of the release of the DNC emails was perfect, in a twisted way. There is more. And HRC's missing emails may not be the only thing they have.

"No modern presidential candidate who trailed in the polls a few weeks after the conventions has gone on to win the popular vote."

This is no ordinary election and a Trump win would be disastrous for all of us and the rest of the world.

Vote for Hillary
Donate time and money to Hillary's campaign
Talk with your friends about your concerns and encourage them to support Hillary
It is time for Mr. Trump to do something bold to bring new positive attention to his campaign. He can promise to return Alaska to Russia and media will stop paying any attention to Mrs. Clinton.

I'm about 20 years younger than Bella, but I'm with her!  My brother who was a history professor for much of his working life says there has not been such a venomous primary/election cycle since the Civil War, and perhaps not ever.  Nor has there ever been such an unfit candidate nominated by a major party in my lifetime nor in several lifetimes before mine.  Dump Trump!
Don't boo, vote!
In your dreams.

Listen to Bella from CT...don't sit back and think Hillary has got the win wrapped up, just based on polls. Get out and vote, especially those in the swing states. Carpool with a neighbor, remind your college-aged children to get their absentee ballots in, wear your "I voted" sticker on election day to remind others to go to the polls.

This piece from the Boston Globe brings in a new twist to the saga of DT and women along with his typical penchant for financially ruining others in the bargain.. http://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2016/04/16/trump/P6jVWXAzaG12Ou...

I'm voting for Trump. I've never voted Republican in my life. I'm also a combat veteran from Ohio. It's unfortunate what you all have turned America into. I can't do any more whiny anti-American morality hating silliness. Polls are polls, they don't accurately predict elections. I'm not letting this extremist liberal takeover of the democratic party ruin my country. Good luck with your interneting you fragile little fellas.

I believe come November 8th Hillary will have a commanding lead and beat the Trumpster easily.

That said, as a lifelong Democrat and native New Yorker who has voted in every election since '60 (JFK) I will not take my confidence for granted, and I cautiously advise all those new youngsters out there not to either. Vote as early and as often (that's an old joke) as you can. Take nothing for granted, ever, in politics, even if you're from NYC.

DD
Manhattan
Well pasties will be women's high fashion once he gets in.

If the final electoral college figures are close then Gary Johnson will give us our first Libertarian presidency.

I am very excited that as a former Bernie supporter ( sent money and helped spread the word) I now truly can vote for someone who is fit to be president and who has no baggage like ClinTrump, the most negatively rated candidates for president in years.

Currently Johnson/Weld are polling 26%+ in Utah and will take its 6 electoral votes. They will win Alaska (3), Idaho ( 26% Mormon, 3), Montana (3), New Hampshire (4) and possibly some other states where people refuse to vote ClinTrump.

We do have a choice this year.

And, via the House, which will pick the president of those who got the most electoral votes if no one gets 270. we will have someone who will make us all proud.

Wednesday, 9PM, EST, Anderson Cooper, will moderate the Libertarian Town Hall on CNN. Millions of voters will tune in and realize that we truly don't have to hold our noses and vote for ClinTrump.

Vote your conscience and finally get someone in the White House we can all be proud of.
